text: - You slaughter your own cows Meg, nice.
Potatoes.
- Grab some while you can.
- Meg's gravy is famous,
it's practically a food group.
- [Babish] Hey, what's up guys.
Welcome back to Binging with Babish,

where this week I'm
delighted to be taking a look
at the steak, eggs and gravy
from my first PG 13 movie, Twister,
particularly Meg's famous gravy

for which we're going to need
a pretty epic beef stock.

So I've got about three
pounds of oxtails here
which are loaded with delicious meats
and marrow and connective tissue.

I'm also going to add
a large Spanish Onion,
roughly chopped into pieces,

a few ribs of celery,
ain't a soup without celery

and a couple of carrots, roughly
chopped, not even peeled.
We're tossing all those in a bowl,
hitting it with a little kosher salt,
three to four tablespoons of tomato paste,

which is both going to
deepen flavor and color
and a drop of vegetable oil.
We're tossing everybody together

until everybody is well
coated in the tomato paste,
and then we're dumping everybody out

onto a rimmed baking sheet
so we can roast them off
in a 425 degree Fahrenheit oven
for anywhere from 30 minutes to one hour.

We want everybody to have
picked up some nice color

and to smell the way you
imagine Nick Offerman smells,
just marvelously meaty.

Now you could simmer this on
the stove top to make stock

but I'm going to expedite the
process in a pressure cooker

along with some fresh
herbs, parsley, and thyme

and a whole head's worth of
garlic, the cloves cut in half.
Then I'm pouring some boiling water
on our roasting pan,

scraping up all the good stuff
off the bottom of the pan,

so we don't waste any
of that delicious flavor
and topping the whole thing up with water.
Then we're cooking this guy
under high pressure for two hours

which is going to extract
as much flavor as possible
from our ingredients and make your kitchen

smell the way you imagine Nick
Offerman's house would smell
if he invited Steven Rinella
and the Brawny man, over for dinner.
Strain that out into a large stockpot,
make sure that you have extracted
all the beefy juices from the solids,
and then we're going to defat this thing

which you can either do
with a ladle like this
or you can fridge it overnight

and scoop off the
hardened fat with a spoon.

Once defatted, I'm going to
place this over medium heat

bring it to a simmer and
reduce it by about 50%,
almost like we're making a demi-glace.

We're going to know we've
done our job correctly,
if we fridge the resultant broth

and it looks like this,
jiggly and jellified
from all the dissolved gelatin
we got out of the meat.

Next step to keep this
breakfast light and healthy,
it is served with mashed potatoes
which looks pretty fluffy and white to me.

So I have about three
pounds of russets here

that I'm peeling and cutting
into about one inch cubes,
dumping into cold water and rinsing,
which is going to remove excess starch,
preventing the potatoes from discoloring
and improving their texture.

They're headed into cold,
heavily salted water
that we're going to bring up to a simmer

and cook for 12 to 15 minutes
until completely tender.

Then we're draining,
putting them back in the pot
and placing them over low heat.

We're going to cook and stir
them for about two minutes.
Meanwhile, on a separate burner,
we've got half a cup of heavy cream
and a quarter cup of butter

which we're going to
gently heat until melted
before pouring into the potatoes,

killing the heat and
mash them all together.
Make sure you season early,
because if you overwork the potatoes,
they're going to get gummy.
Once you've got them nice and smooth,
make sure you taste for seasoning,
and if they're good to go,

it's time to cover them
up and keep them warm,
while we get our gravy going.
Once again to max out meaty flavor,
I want to use meaty fats in our room,
and having slaughtered her own cows,

I figured Meg has access to
something like this, beef suet.

A saturated fat found
around the animal's kidneys
that has a nice high smoke point.
To render out the fat from the solids,

I'm just going to heat
it over medium low heat
until it melts out, then strain it
into my intended gravy making vessel.
Now you don't have to use suet,
you could use beef tallow or bacon fat,
why don't we add some bacon fat.

This gravy is after
all supposed to be like
its own food group.

In a separate pan, I'm
just melting the stock
so that it is ladleable
and I'm heating the fat over medium heat,

until shimmering and
then adding equal amounts
of all purpose flour,
about four tablespoons worth.

Whisking and cooking that
for about three minutes,
until it's nice and blonde
and then slowly ladling in the hot stock,
whisking constantly and making sure
that it's fully incorporated
before adding another ladle full
which is going to help prevent us ending
up with a lumpy gravy.
Once we've added about four cups of stock,

we're going cook this
guy for maybe 10 minutes
until it's nice and thick.

Season generously with kosher
salt and freshly ground pepper

and then to both darken the
color and deepen the flavor,
I'm going to add something
that I think my mom would have added,
a little splash of Gravy Master,
the caramelized sugar and spice mixture

that takes this gravy from
homemade to down home,
mix everybody together,

cook it a little longer if
you want it a little thicker

and as always give it a
taste, not just for seasoning

but because you can really eat
this stuff by the spoonful.

Next and last, we are contending
with our steak and eggs.
I have a Rib Eye here,

which I'm gonna blast with
heat in a cast iron pan
until we get a lovely crust on both sides.
Then once the crust is formed,
we're going to lower the heat,
so we can finish cooking the steak through
and this is when we add our eggs,
which were inexplicably added to the pan,
when the steak was still raw in the movie,

I assumed this was just
a food styling oversight.

We're taking the steak off
before the eggs finish cooking.

So it has an opportunity
to rest for a little bit,

removing the eggs once
they've reached a state
of sunnyside up doneness

and plating with a proud,
heavy pile of potatoes,

which we are of course going
to make into our very own
active gravy volcano,

and there you have it,
the breakfast of choice

for a lovable scruffy,
misfit storm chasers,

their uptight fiances
and Rochester native,

may he rest in peace,
Phillip Seymour Hoffman,

and even though I had
literally just eaten lunch,
I entered it into the,
"As Clean a Plate as Possible Club."
